DT Article
TI [The Cychrus F., 1794, in the Caucasian Region (Coleoptera, Carabidae).]
FT Le genre Cychrus F., 1794, dans la region Caucasienne (Coleoptera,
   Carabidae).
AU Deuve, Thierry
   Prunier, Daniel
SO Coleopteres
VL 20
IS 10
PS 85-114
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper we give short description of the Cychrus fauna in the
   Caucasian area, with identification and morphological definition of four
   species: Cychrus signatus Faldermann, 1836, C. aeneus Fischer, 1823, C.
   rosti Roeschke, 1907, and C. starcki Reitter, 1888. Each of these
   species is polytypic as illustrated by morphological variation of the
   male genitalia. Four new subspecies are described: C. aeneus rikoticola
   n. subsp. from Imereti, C. aeneus japoshvilii n. subsp. from
   Samtskhe-Javakheti, C. rosti retezari n. subsp. from Eastern Abkhazia
   and C. rosti lebardensis n. subsp. from Samegreli. A discussion is given
   about the typical locality of the respective taxa aeneus Fischer, 1823,
   and signatus Faldermann, 1836. C. rosti Roeschke, 1907, is upgraded to
   the specific rank. C. volkovi Berlov, 1997, is considered to be a new
   synonym of C. aeneus aeneus Fischer, 1823, and C. inessae Berlov, 1997,
   to be a new synonym of C. rosti rosti Roeschke, 1907. C. inessae
   sharovae Berlov, 1997, C. makarovi Berlov, 1997, C. tillyi Berlov, 1997,
   C. belousovi Berlov, 1997, C. milyaevi Berlov, 1997, and C. dhordaini
   Prunier, 2012, are considered to be more or less valid subspecies of C.
   rosti Roeschke, 1907 (n. stat.), and C. zamotajlovi Berlov, 1997, to be
   a subspecies of C. starcki Reitter, 1888 (n. stat.). A lectotype is
   designated for Cychrus rosti Roeschke, 1907. Lectotypes are respectively
   designated for C. signatus Faldermann, 1836, and for C. rosti Roeschke,
   1907.
C1 Deuve, Thierry; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Systemat & Evolut Entomol, CP
   50,45 Rue Buffon, Paris, F-75005, France, France.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Entomology; Reproductive Biology;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 1265-3357
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Status; General morphology; Reproduction;
   Reproductive system; Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cychrus [General morphology /  / systematics] [Aedeagus /  / ]

TI A REVISION OF THE NEW ZEALAND SPECIES OF THE GENUS SAGOLA SHARP
   (COLEOPTERA: STAPHYLINIDAE: PSELAPHINAE: FARONITAE).
AU Park, J.-S.
   Carlton, C.E.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 68
PS 1-156
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The pselaphine genus Sagola Sharp (type species: Sagola misella Sharp)
   comprises 143 species occurring in the New Zealand region and divided
   among 31 species-groups. Ninety-five species are described as new
   herein: Sagola coromandelensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola
   northlandensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola taranakiensis Park
   and Carlton, new species; Sagola kuscheli Park and Carlton, new species;
   Sagola newtoni Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola thorpei Park and

   clunieae Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola turretensis Park and
   Carlton, new species; Sagola otagoensis Park and Carlton, new species;
   Sagola southlandensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola huvali Park

   species ; Sagola moehauensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola
   horokakaensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola marrisi Park and
   Carlton, new species; Sagola boothi Park and Carlton, new species;
   Sagola prowellae Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola mackenziensis
   Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola sheldoni Park and Carlton, new
   species; Sagola mercuryensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola
   cuvierensis Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola buckleyi Park and
   Carlton, new species; Sagola brumfieldi Park and Carlton, new species;
   Sagola otteai Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola boudreauxae Park and
   Carlton, new species; Sagola taegyui Park and Carlton, new species;
   Sagola hanae Park and Carlton, new species; Sagola gyudongi Park and

   synonymized: Sagola cilipes Broun under Sagola hirtalis Broun; Sagola
   basalis Broun and Sagola indiscreta Broun under Sagola convexa Broun;

   under Sagola parva Sharp; Sagola elevata Broun under Sagola denticollis
   Broun; Sagola crassulipes Broun under Sagola sulcator Broun; Sagola
   brevifossa Broun and Sagola subcuneata Broun under Sagola rustica Broun;
   Sagola clavatella Broun, Sagola grata Broun, and Sagola posticalis Broun
   under Sagola sharpi Raffray; Sagola occipitalis Broun under Sagola
   spiniventris Broun; Sagola fasciculata Broun under Sagola strialis
   Broun; Sagola dickensis Broun and Sagola suturalis Broun under Sagola
   anisarthra Broun; Sagola unicalis Broun under Sagola socia Broun; Sagola
   brevitarsis Broun, Sagola citima Broun, Sagola cognata Broun, Sagola
   diversa Broun, and Sagola parallela Broun under Sagola excavata Broun;
   Sagola electa Broun, Sagola fulvipennis Broun, and Sagola macronyx Broun
   under Sagola notabilis Broun; Sagola bifoveiceps Broun, Sagola
   biimpressa Broun, and Sagola nitida Broun under Sagola monstrosa
   Reitter; Sagola foveiventris Broun under S. misella Sharp; Sagola
   acuminata Broun, Sagola disparata Broun, Sagola fuscipalpis Broun,
   Sagola rufescens Broun, and Sagola striatifrons Broun under Sagola
   prisca Sharp; Sagola elongata Broun, Sagola longipes Broun, Sagola
   mimica Broun, and Sagola ruficeps Broun under Sagola major Sharp; Sagola
   sobrina Broun under Sagola insignis Broun; Sagola distorta Broun under
   Sagola hectorii Broun; Sagola brevisternis Broun, Sagola confusa Broun,
   Sagola frontalis Raffray, Sagola fulva Broun, Sagola halli Broun, Sagola
   immota Broun, Sagola laetula Broun, Sagola laminata Broun, Sagola latula
   Broun, Sagola lawsoni Broun, and Sagola osculans Broun under Sagola
   bipunctata Broun; Sagola aemula Broun, Sagola affinis Broun, Sagola
   bipuncticeps Broun, Sagola cordiceps Broun, and Sagola remixta Broun
   under Sagola robustula Broun; Sagola bilobata Broun, Sagola fagicola
   Broun, Sagola minuscula Broun, and Sagola pallidula Broun under Sagola
   genalis Broun new synonymies. We also designate lectotypes for Sagola
   terricola Broun, S. rugifrons Broun, Sagola valida Broun, Sagola
   arboricola Broun, S. notabilis Broun, S. misella Sharp, S. prisca Sharp,
   Sagola eminens Broun, S. robustula Broun, and Sagola pertinax Broun.
   Keys, habitus photographs, and line drawings of diagnostic characters
   for each species are provided.
C1 Park, J.-S.; Louisiana State Univ, Ctr Agr, LSB 404, Baton Rouge, LA,
   70803, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0010-065X

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103019165
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15103017532
DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC REVISION OF THE GENUS PARANOTA MONROS AND VIANA, 1949
   (COLEOPTERA: CHRYSOMELIDAE: CASSIDINAE: DORYNOTINI).
AU Simoes, Marianna V.P. (mariannavpsimoes@gmail.com) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 68
IS 4
PS 631-655
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The Neotropical genus Paranota Monros and Viana, 1949 is revised and its
   species redescribed. Paranota apiculata (Boheman 1854), new combination,
   is transferred from the genus Dorynota Chevrolat, 1836, Paranota Rugosa
   (Wagener, 1881), revised status and new combination, is resurrected from
   synonymy with Paranota ensifera (Boheman, 1854), and Paranota parallela
   (Blanchard, 1837) is found to not be a member Paranota and transferred
   to the genus Dorynota. Following this revision, Paranota now contains
   five species. In addition, the morphology of the male and female
   genitalia of selected species is reviewed in detail. An identification
   key to species, updated distribution records, and maps are provided.
C1 Simoes, Marianna V.P.; Univ Kansas, Div Entomol, Lawrence, KS, 66045,
   USA, USA.
EM mariannavpsimoes@gmail.com
RI Simoes, Marianna/C-3369-2019
OI Simoes, Marianna/0000-0003-4401-5530
SC Zoology
SN 0010-065X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Paranota [Neotropical region /  / Distribution; taxonomic revision]. 
   Paranota apiculata [Brazil /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Paranota ensifera [Brazil / Minas Gerais / New record; systematics]
   [Colombia /  / ]. 
   Paranota spinosa [Argentina / Formosa / New record; systematics] [Brazil
   / Goias & Sao Paulo / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Batonota rugosa - Wagner 1881 (Chrysomelidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Paranota ensifera (Boheman 1854), p. 649; Referred to, Paranota, p.
   648]. 
   Dorynota (Dorynota) apiculata - (Boheman 1854) (Chrysomelidae):
   [Referred to, Paranota, p. 651]. 
   Dorynota (Dorynota) parallela - Blanchard 1837 (Chrysomelidae):
   [Combination revalidated, Transferred back from Paranota, p. 652]. 
   Paranota - Monros & Viana 1949 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P. 633;
   Key to species, P. 638]. 
   Paranota apiculata - (Boheman 1854) (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P.
   651; Comb nov, Transferred from Dorynota (Dorynota), p. 651; New
   record]. 
   Paranota ensifera - (Boheman 1854) (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P.
   639; Removal from synonymy, Batonota rugosa Wagner 1881, p. 649; New
   record].

DT Article
TI A NEW GENUS AND SPECIES OF DYNASTINAE (COLEOPTERA: SCARABAEIDAE) FROM
   THE GALAPAGOS ISLANDS, ECUADOR, OTHER NEW SPECIES OF CYCLOCEPHALINI,
   PENTODONTINI, AND PHILEURINI FROM SOUTH AMERICA, AND A REVISED KEY TO
   THE GENERA OF NEW WORLD PENTODONTINI.
AU Ratcliffe, Brett C. (bratcliffe1@unl.edu) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 68
IS 4
PS 663-680
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The following new scarab beetles are described from South America:
   Cyclocephala dupuisi Ratcliffe, new species, from Bolivia and
   Stenocrates caiporae Ratcliffe, new species, from Brazil (both
   Cyclocephalini); Hiekeianus halophilus Ratcliffe, new species, from
   Peru, Neoryctes similis Ratcliffe, new species, from Ecuador, and
   Adelaeus anachoretus Ratcliffe, new genus and new species, from the
   Galapagos Islands, Ecuador (all Pentodontini); and Hemiphileurus
   cornutus Ratcliffe, new species, from Colombia (Phileurini). Each new
   taxon is provided with a description, supporting illustrations, a
   diagnosis to distinguish it from similar taxa, and distribution. A
   revised key to the genera of New World Pentodontini is provided to
   include Adelaeus.

DT Article
TI CLASSIFICATION, NATURAL HISTORY, AND EVOLUTION OF THE CHECKERED BEETLE
   GENUS PUJOLICLERUS PIC (COLEOPTERA: CLERIDAE: PELONIINAE).
AU Opitz, Weston (opitz@kwu.edu) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 68
IS 4
PS 727-756
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Pujoliclerus Pic is redefined to include 30 species as
   follows: Pujoliclerus helvinus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus
   maracayensis Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus modestus Pic; Pujoliclerus
   prolatus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus bilineatus Opitz, new species;
   Pujoliclerus calceatus (Chevrolat); Pujoliclerus corumba Opitz, new
   species; Pujoliclerus flavolimbatus (Spinola); Pujoliclerus ovatus
   Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus wappesi Opitz, new species;
   Pujoliclerus amplus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus flavoapicalus
   Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus gilvus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus
   hermani Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus orellana Opitz, new species;
   Pujoliclerus oxinus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus alajuela Opitz, new
   species; Pujoliclerus megacavus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus
   alboordinus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus apolegmus Opitz, new
   species; Pujoliclerus casselorum Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus
   catarina Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus macilentus Opitz, new species;
   Pujoliclerus megalus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus argus Opitz, new
   species; Pujoliclerus aspigalbus Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus flora
   Opitz, new species; Pujoliclerus posticalis (Chapin); Pujoliclerus
   ostrinus Opitz, new species; and Pujoliclerus pallidus Opitz, new
   species. Lectotypes are designated for P. modestus and P. calceatus, and
   Pseudichnea varicollis Schenkling is synonymyzed with P. calceatus and
   Pelonium flavomarginatum Chevrolat with P. flavolimbatus. According to
   morphological analysis, Pujoliclerus species are thought to be
   carnivorous on lignicolous insects. Moreover, these species are thought
   to originate in the highlands of South America with several
   infiltrations into terrain of Central America. A discussion of
   nomenclatural issues with the Enopliinae genus Pseudichnea Schenkling is
   presented, as well a treatise on natural history, a key to
   species-groups and species, a discussion of interspecies-group
   evolutionary relationships, and a phylogenetic tree generated with
   Winclada in coordination with NONA.
C1 Opitz, Weston; Florida Dept Agr & Consumer Serv, Florida State Collect

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS NEACRATUS ALONSO-ZARAZAGA, LYAL, BARTOLOZZI,
   AND SFORZI (COLEOPTERA: BRENTIDAE: ACRATINI) FROM CENTRAL AMERICA.
AU Mantilleri, Antoine (amantill@mnhn.fr) 
   Lanuza-Garay, Alfredo
   Bartolozzi, Luca
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 68
IS 4
PS 757-761
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Neacratus antennatus Mantilleri, Lanuza-Garay, and Bartolozzi, new
   species, a straight-snout weevil from Central America, is described and
   illustrated. Although the new taxon shows very peculiar antennal and
   elytral apices, it is provisionally included in the genus Neacratus
   Alonso-Zarazaga, Lyal, Bartolozzi, and Sforzi, 1999. The new species is
   compared with other Neacratus species, particularly to Neacratus
   glabratus (Lund, 1800), the type species of the genus.

DT Article
TI A New Ricefish of the Genus Oryzias (Beloniformes, Adrianichthyidae)
   from Lake Tiu, Central Sulawesi, Indonesia.
AU Mokodongan, Daniel F. (dh4ni31.ichi.san@gmail.com) 
   Tanaka, Rieko
   Yamahira, Kazunori
SO Copeia
VL 3
PS 561-567
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB We describe Oryzias soerotoi, a new species of ricefish, from Lake Tiu,
   Central Sulawesi, Indonesia. The new species is distinguished from all
   other species in the genus Oryzias in Sulawesi by combination of
   brilliant orange coloration in the dorsal and ventral margins of the
   caudal fins of adult males, 30-32 scales along the lateral midline, 9-10
   pectoral-fin rays, head lengths of 21.9-24.9% SL, anal-fin base lengths
   of 23.7-29.7% SL, and maximum SL up to 32.1 mm. The orange margins of
   the caudal fins of males become more brilliant during courtship. Kami
   mendiskripsi Oryzias soerotoi, satu jenis baru ikan padi dari Danau Tiu,
   Sulawesi Tengah, Indonesia. Jenis baru ini dengan mudah dapat dibedakan
   dari semua jenis anggota genus Oryzias di Sulawesi dengan adanya
   kombinasi warna jingga yang sangat mencolok di bagian atas dan bawah
   sirip ekor pada jantan dewasa, 30-32 jumlah sisik sepanjang garis sisi,
   9-10 jumlah jari-jari sirip dada, ukuran kepala pendek 21.9-24.9% SL,
   panjang pada pangkal sirip anal 23.7-29.7% SL, dan maksimal SL mencapai
   32.1 mm. Warna jingga di sirip ekor pada jantan menjadi lebih mencolok
   selama proses percumbuan.
C1 Mokodongan, Daniel F.; Univ Ryukyus, Trop Biosphere Res Ctr, Okinawa,
   9030213, Japan, Japan.
EM dh4ni31.ichi.san@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Oryzias soerotoi [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Beloniformes, Adrianichthyidae

AN ZOOR15103017150
DT Article
TI Taxonomic Revision of Oiketicoides HEYLAERTS, 1881 from the Iberian
   Peninsula (Lepidoptera: Psychidae, Oiketicinae).
FT Taxonomische Revision von Oiketicoides HEYLAERTS, 1881 von der
   lberischen Halbinsel (Lepidoptera: Psychidae, Oiketicinae).
AU Sobczyk, Thomas (ThomasSobczyk@aol.com) 
   Arnscheid, Wilfried R.
   Nuss, Matthias
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 124
IS 4
PS 215-226
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Oiketicoides HEYLAERTS, 1881 species from the Iberian Peninsula are
   studied based on morphological characters and the DNA-barcode. The
   results reveal that in addition to Oiketicoides febretta (BOYER DE
   FONSCOLOMBE, 1835) and Oiketicoides eganai (AGENJo, 1962) occur three
   other previously undescribed species on the peninsula. They are
   described in this paper as Oiketicoides aragonensis sp. nov.,
   Oiketicoides hispanolusitania sp. nov., and Oiketicoides obscura sp.
   nov. There are no reliable records of Oiketicoides tedaldii (HEYLAERTS,
   1882) from the Iberian Peninsula. Notes on biology as well as an
   identification key based on male characters are given.
C1 Sobczyk, Thomas; Diesterwegstr 28, Hoyerswerda, D-02977, Germany,
   Germany.
EM ThomasSobczyk@aol.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity

   Key; General morphology; Genetics; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe

   / ] [Europe / Iberian Peninsula / Key to species] [ /  / biology;
   distribution]. 
   Oiketicoides aragonensis; Oiketicoides obscura [Spain /  / New species].

TI Taxonomical notes on some species of Therates LATREILLE, 1817 from
   Xizang, China (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae).
AU Wiesner, Juergen (juergen.wiesner@wolfsburg.de) 
   Bi, Wen-Xuan
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 124
IS 4
PS 233-236
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The rates tanjuanjieae sp. nov. is described. It is distinguished by the
   green metallic color of the elytra and absence of an apical lunule or
   spot. Therates motoensis TAN, 1981 is re-established and redescribed. It
   is distinguished by the thickened basal joints of the metatarsi and
   color of the labrum.

DT Article
TI Results of a short collecting trip to the Central Lowveld in the Limpopo
   Province, South Africa, with description of Deltote johnjoannoui sp.
   nov. (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae).
AU Mey, Wolfram (wolfram.mey@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Kuehne, Lars
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 124
IS 4
PS 239-245
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB During a two-nights collecting campaign at Hongony Lodge near Hoedspruit
   in South Africa macro- and micromoths were collected by light
   trapping/collecting. A total of 412 species were collected with
   Microlepidoptera and Macrolepidoptera making up about 50 % each. A long
   series of an undescribed species of Noctuidae was sampled which is
   described herein as Deltote johnjoannoui sp. nov. First country records
   are provided for the genera Aphanostola MEYRICK, 1931 (Gelechiidae) and
   Termioptycha MEYRICK, 1889 (Pyralidae). Elophila obliteralis WALKER,
   1859 (Crambidae) and Plagoa zam-beziella HAMPSON, 1911 (Pyralidae) are
   recorded from South Africa for the first time.
C1 Mey, Wolfram; Leibniz Inst Evolut & Biodiversitatsforsch, Museum
   Naturkunde, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, D-10115, Germany, Germany.
EM wolfram.mey@mfn-berlin.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8843
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Aphanostola; Elophila obliteralis; Plagoa zambeziella; Termioptycha
   [South Africa /  / New record]. 
   Deltote johnjoannoui [South Africa /  / New species]. 
   Lepidoptera [South Africa / Limpopo, Central Lowveld, Hoedspruit area /
   Faunal list; new record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

DT Article
TI A Novel Paramyxean Parasite, Marteilia granula sp nov (Cercozoa), from
   the Digestive Gland of Manila Clam Ruditapes philippinarum in Japan.
AU Itoh, Naoki (aitoh-nk@mail.ecc.u-tokyo.ac.jp) 
   Yamamoto, Toshihiro
   Kang, Hyun-Sil
   Choi, Kwang-Sik
   Green, Timothy J.
   Carrasco, Noelia
   Awaji, Masahiko
   Chow, Seinen
SO Fish Pathology
VL 49
IS 4
PS 181-193
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 24
AB A paramyxean parasite infection was observed in the epithelial cells of
   the stomach, intestine, and digestive diverticula of Manila clam
   Ruditapes philippinarum collected from Odawa Bay, Japan. The mean
   detection frequency between April 2010 and September 2011 as revealed by
   histology was 8.9% with a maximum monthly frequency of 28.6%, but
   remarkable mass mortality was not recognized during the study period.
   Sporulation of the parasites involves repeated production of
   intracellular cells, and a primary cell contains 8 secondary cells, in
   which 4 multicellular spore cells are produced. Several large
   eosinophilic granules formed in the cytoplasm of secondary cells during
   the final maturation process. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
   revealed that spore cells consisted of the innermost, intermediate and
   outermost cells, indicating that this parasite is a member of the genus
   Marteilia. TEM observations also revealed that the cell membrane of
   mature spores was lined with an electron-dense monolayer, which has not
   been reported from other species in the genus Marteilia. Determined SSU
   rRNA gene sequence of this parasite was apparently different from
   previously described Marteilia species, and this species was identified
   as Marteilia granula n. sp., a new species in the genus Marteilia, Order
   Paramyxida, Phylum Cercozoa. Our results identify for the first time the
   parasite species of the genus Marteilia infecting the Manila clam in
   Japan.
C1 Itoh, Naoki; Tohoku Univ, Grad Sch Agr Sci, Sendai, Miyagi, 9818555,
   Japan, Japan.
EM aitoh-nk@mail.ecc.u-tokyo.ac.jp
RI Choi, Kwang-Sik Albert/B-5367-2011; Querol, Noelia
   Carrasco/AAF-6702-2019
OI Querol, Noelia Carrasco/0000-0002-5876-7082; Green,
   Timothy/0000-0001-5163-9312
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0388-788X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Marteilia [Molluscan hosts / Ruditapes philippinarum / New record]
   [North Pacific / Japan / ]. 
   Marteilia granula [Molluscan hosts / Ruditapes philippinarum / New
   parasite species] [North Pacific / Japan / New species from molluscan
   host]. 
   Ruditapes philippinarum [Protozoan parasites / Marteilia granula / New
   parasite species] [ / Marteilia / New record] [North Pacific / Japan /
   New protozoan parasite species] [ /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs; Protozoans

   Protozoa, Ascetospora

   Marteilia (Ascetospora): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Marteilia granula (Ascetospora): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), Parasite of
   Ruditapes philippinarum (Mollusca), p. 187; Parasite].

DT Article
TI A NEW SAPROXYLIC PALEONURINI (COLLEMBOLA, NEANURIDAE) SPECIES FROM NORTH
   AMERICA WITH THE FIRST RECORD OF GALANURA AGNIESKAE SMOLIS, 2000 FROM
   THE CONTINENT.
AU Smolis, Adrian
   Kadej, Marcin (marcin.kadej@uni.wroc.pl) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1386-1394
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Paleonura saproxylica sp. nov. was discovered in the Cascade Range of
   Oregon State, where it can be observed in rotten logs of coniferous tree
   species. This new species has the most northly distribution within this
   mostly tropical and subtropical genus. It is most similar to 2 other
   North American species Paleonura, P. anops (Christiansen & Bellinger,
   1980) and P. petebellingeri Palacios-Vargas & Simon Benito, 2007. These
   species differ in many chaetotactic features. The first record of the
   other saproxylic Paleonurini from North America, Galanura agnieskae
   Smolis, 2000, is also provided. This species was found in rotten logs in
   boreal balsam-fir-white birch forests of the Canadian province of
   Quebec.
C1 Kadej, Marcin; Univ Wroclaw, Fac Biol Sci, Przybyszewskiego 63-77,
   Wroclaw, PL-51148, Poland, Poland.
EM marcin.kadej@uni.wroc.pl
RI Kadej, Marcin/E-5916-2018
OI Kadej, Marcin/0000-0001-5983-0402

SN 0015-4040

   America; USA

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

TI CONTRIBUTION TO KNOWLEDGE OF THE DERMESTIDAE (COLEOPTERA) FROM
   AFGHANISTAN WITH DESCRIPTION OF THREE NEW SPECIES.
AU Hava, Jiri
   Kadej, Marcin (marcin.kadej@uni.wroc.pl) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1414-1423
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Three new species Orphilus kabakovi sp. nov., Orphinus (s. str.)
   kabakovi sp. nov., Ctesias (Decemctesias) mroczkowskii sp. nov.
   (Coleoptera: Demestidae) are described from Afghanistan. The habitus,
   antenna, genitalia are illustrated and compared with related species.
   The species Attagenus indicus Kalik, 1954 and Anthrenus (Anthrenodes)
   amoenulus Reitter, 1896 are newly recorded from Afghanistan.
   Morphological details with dorsal variability of Attagenus indicus
   Kalik, 1954 are illustrated for the first time. A revised list of the
   species from Afghanistan is given.

TI A KEY TO THE GENERA OF EMPOASCINI (HEMIPTERA: CICADELLIDAE:
   TYPHLOCYBINAE) IN CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF TWO NEW GENERA AND TWO NEW
   SPECIES.
AU Qin, Daozheng (qindaozh@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
   Lu, Sihan
   Dietrich, Christopher H.
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1493-1510
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Two new microleafhopper genera, Keumiata Qin & Dietrich gen. nov. and
   Flaviata Lu & Qin gen. nov. are described based on 2 new species, K.
   orientalis Qin & Dietrich sp. nov. and F. variata Lu & Qin sp. nov. from
   southwest China and Thailand. Both new genera are assigned to the
   typhlocybine tribe Empoascini. A key to the known genera of the tribe
   from China is provided and the differences between each new genus and
   closely related genera are discussed.

DT Article
TI SINGULAR FAUNA OF ENTOMOBRYIDAE (COLLEMBOLA) FROM 'LAND OF PASSES' IN
   THE HIMALAYAS, INDIA.
AU Baquero, Enrique (ebaquero@unav.es) 
   Mandal, Gurupada
   Jordana, Rafael
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1554-1587
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB The present study of collembolan fauna is based on collections made
   during Aug-Sep 2008 from Ladakh district of Jammu and Kashmir, India, as
   a part of the "Cold Desert Expedition" of Zoological Survey of India.
   Ladakh, which means "land of many passes", is in northwestern India,
   bordering on China (Xinjiang and Tibet), and on its northwest it borders
   on Pakistan. The collembolans were collected from different parts of
   Ladakh district. The collections were mainly made through aspirators
   from leaf litter, mosses, under stones, a flower garden, agricultural
   fields, an embankment of a river, wetland and sand dunes. For the genera
   Corynothrix and Himalanura, an artic-alpine disjunction was found.
   Lepidocyrtus (Allocyrtus) lepidornatus was referred for a third time
   after 2 previous references from Philippines and Borneo. Seven new
   species belonging to Entomobryidae family are described: Entomobrya
   diskitensis sp. nov., E. ladakhi sp. nov., E. choudhurii sp. nov., E.
   mehtai sp. nov., Himalanura baijali sp. nov., Seira nidarensis sp. nov.
   and S. hazrai sp. nov.
C1 Baquero, Enrique; Univ Navarra, Dept Environm Biol, Navarra, 31008,
   Spain, Spain.
EM ebaquero@unav.es

TI A TAXONOMIC REVIEW OF STACHYOTIS (LEPIDOPTERA: YPONOMEUTOIDEA:
   PLUTELLIDAE) WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES FROM CHINA.
AU Sohn, Jae-Cheon (jsohn@umd.edu) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1588-1593
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Stachyotis (Lepidoptera, Yponomeutoidea, Plutellidae) is
   reviewed by re-description of the type species, Stachyotis epichrysa
   Meyrick from Sri Lanka and description of a new species, S. chunshengwui
   sp. nov. from China. These 2 congeners are distinguished from each other
   in their forewing patterns and male genitalia. The diagnostic features
   of Stachyotis are proposed from the forewing venation, structures of the
   second sternite and the tergites, and the male genitalia. A possible
   association of Stachyotis and Orthenches-group is discussed.
C1 Sohn, Jae-Cheon; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, Washington, DC,
   20560, USA, USA.

TI DESCRIPTION OF ALOCONOTA ELONGATA SP NOV (COLEOPTERA: STAPHYLINIDAE:

AB A new species of Callirhytis Forster 1869 ( Hymenoptera: Cynipidae:
   Cynipini) is described from Panama: Callirhytis cameroni sp. nov.
   Callirhytis cameroni is the first species of genus Callirhytis 'sensu

TI NEW SPECIES OF SENSILLONYCHIURUS (COLLEMBOLA: ONYCHIURIDAE:
   ONYCHIURINAE) IN HEILONGJIANG PROVINCE, CHINA.
AU Sun, Xin
   Wu, Donghui (wudonghui@iga.ac.cn) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1718-1725
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species, Sensillonychiurus pseudogeminus sp. nov. and
   Sensillonychiurus zhuajiensis sp. nov., are reported from Heilongjiang
   Province, China. S. pseudogeminus sp. nov. is very similar to the S.
   geminus Pomorski & Sveenkova 2006, but it can recognized by shorter
   unguiculus, longer anal spines and presence of sternal parapseudocelli
   on Abd. II and Abd. IV instead of pseudocelli. Sensillonychiurus
   zhuajiensis sp. nov. can easily be distinguished from other known
   congeners by its peculiar dorsal pso formula (32/144/44453).

TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF PARARRHOPALITES (COLLEMBOLA: SYMPHYPLEONA:
   SMINTHURIDAE) IN BRAZIL.
AU Zeppelini, Douglas (zeppelini@daad-alumni.de) 
   Brito, Roniere A.
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 97
IS 4
PS 1733-1744
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of springtails (Symphypleona: Sminthuridae),
   Pararrhopalites sideroicus sp. nov. and Pararrhopalites palaciosi sp.
   nov. are described. The species come from very different environments,
   the first is a cave dweller in iron caves and the other comes from
   tropical Atlantic forest leaf litter. They were found only from type
   localities, in Southeastern and Northeastern Brazil respectively. An
   identification key is provided for all members of the genus.

AB A new species of Thespieus Godman, 1900 (Hesperiidae, Hesperiini),
   Thespieus maacki sp. nov., is described from high altitude grasslands on
   Aracatuba Mountain peak, Tijucas do Sul, Parana, Brazil. Similar
   habitats surrounding the type locality were also sampled, but this
   species was never recorded elsewhere. The most similar species Thespieus
   caraca Evans, 1955 is also illustrated and compared, in order to provide
   clear diagnostic characters for species identification.

DT Article
TI Genetic diversity of the harmful family Kareniaceae (Gymnodiniales,
   Dinophyceae) in France, with the description of Karlodinium gentienii sp
   nov.: A new potentially toxic dinoflagellate.
AU Nezan, Elisabeth (elisabeth.nezan@ifremer.fr) 
   Siano, Raffaele
   Boulben, Sylviane
   Six, Christophe
   Bilien, Gwenael
   Cheze, Karine
   Duval, Audrey
   Le Panse, Sophie
   Quere, Julien
   Chomerat, Nicolas
SO Harmful Algae
VL 40
PS 75-91
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 3
U2 45
AB The family Kareniaceae is mostly known in France for recurrent blooms of
   Karenia mikimotoi in the Atlantic, English Channel, and Mediterranean
   Sea and for the unusual green discoloration in the saltwater lagoon of
   Diana (Corsica) caused by Karlodinium corsicum in April 1994. In terms
   of diversity, this taxonomic group was long overlooked owing to the
   difficult identification of these small unarmored dinoflagellates. In
   this study, thanks to the molecular characterization performed on single
   cells from field samples and cultures, twelve taxonomic units were
   assigned to the known genera Karenia, Karlodinium and Takayama, whereas
   one could not be affiliated to any described genus. The molecular
   phylogeny inferred from the D1-D2 region of the LSU rDNA showed that
   five of them formed a sister taxon of a known species, and could not be
   identified at species-level, on the basis of molecular analysis only.
   Among these latter taxa, one Karlodinium which was successfully cultured
   was investigated by studying the external morphological features (using
   two procedures for cells fixation), ultrastructure, pigment composition,
   and haemolytic activity. The results of our analyses corroborate the
   genetic results in favour of the erection of Karlodinium gentienii sp.
   nov., which possesses an internal complex system of trichocysts
   connected to external micro-processes particularly abundant in the
   epicone, and a peculiar pigment composition. In addition, preliminary
   assays showed a haemolytic activity. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Nezan, Elisabeth; IFREMER, Stn Biol Marine, Pl Croix,BP 40537,
   Concarneau, F-29185, France, France.
EM elisabeth.nezan@ifremer.fr

   luminescence; Colour; Genetics; Evolution; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean;

DT Article
TI The helminth community of the Iberian hare, Lepus granatensis
   (Lagomorpha: Leporidae), in the province of Granada, Spain.
AU Segovia, J.M. (mario.v.fuentes@uv.es) 
   Vila, T.
   Vargas, J.M.
   Fuentes, M.V.
   Feliu, C.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 51
IS 4
PS 281-287
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB The helminth community of the Iberian hare, Lepus granatensis, in the
   southern Spanish province of Granada was analysed, thorough the study of
   487 individuals shot by hunters between November 1998 and October 1999.
   Six helminth species were found: Mosgovoyia pectinata (Cestoda);
   Trichostrongylus retortaeformis, Nematodiroides zembrae, Nematodirus
   sp., Passalurus ambiguus and Micipsella numidica (Nematoda). N. zembrae
   and M. pectinata (62.4 % and 17.2 %, respectively) were the only
   component species found. The predominance of helminth species with a
   direct life cycle is noteworthy. These two component species were
   significantly influenced by season of capture. Other factors, such as
   host age and municipality of capture, influenced the prevalences and/or
   abundances of the component species, while host sex did not exert any
   important role. These variations, determined by extrinsic and/or
   intrinsic factors, in the helminth community could be related to the
   ecology of the Iberian hare, mainly diet, habitat and behaviour.

   Barcelona, E-08028, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI Larval trematodes in bithyniid snails (Gastropoda: Bithyniidae) in the
   lake-rivers systems from the steppe zone (The West Siberian Plain,
   Russia).
AU Serbina, E.A. (serbina_elena_an@mail.ru) 
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 51
IS 4
PS 293-300
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A survey of cercariae and metacercariae (Trematoda, Digenea) from
   bithyniid snails (Gastropoda: Bithyniidae) in lake-river systems in
   Northern Kulunda (of the steppe zone of the West Siberia Plain) is
   presented. The role of Bithynia tentaculata (Linne, 1758) and Bithynia
   troscheli (Paasch, 1842) as the first intermediate hosts and as the
   second intermediate hosts of trematodes in the study area was
   accomplished for the first time. Twelve species of cercariae (8
   families) and 12 species of metacercariae (6 families) were found in
   bithyniid snails. Altogether, bithyniid snails were infected with 23
   trematode species including 16 genera in 11 families. New Cercariae
   Holostephanus sp. and five original species of trematode metacercariae,
   were discovered in bithyniid snails of the steppe zone of the West
   Siberia Plain. The dominant cercariae were those of the families
   Prosthogonimidae and Lecithodendriidae. The most prevalent metacercariae
   were Echinoparyphium aconiatum Dietz, 1909 and E. recurvatum Linstow,
   1873 (both family Echinostomatidae) and Cyathocotyle bithyniae
   Sudarikov, 1974 (Cyathocotylidae). B. troscheli infected by trematode
   parthenitae of Holostephanus sp. was detected in the Russia for the
   first time.
C1 Serbina, E.A.; Russian Acad Sci Frunze, Inst Systemat & Ecol Anim, St

EM serbina_elena_an@mail.ru

   Bithyniidae [Digenean parasites /  / Larval parasite survey] [Russia /

   [Russia / West Siberian Plain, Northern Kulunda / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15103018795
DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC REVISION OF THE PSEUDOGEKKO COMPRESICORPUS COMPLEX (REPTILIA:
   SQUAMATA: GEKKONIDAE), WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF THREE NEW SPECIES.
AU Siler, Cameron D. (camsiler@ou.edu) 
   Welton, Luke J.
   Davis, Drew R.
   Watters, Jessa L.
   Davey, Conner S.
   Diesmos, Arvin C.
   Diesmos, Mae L.
   Brown, Rafe M.
SO Herpetological Monographs
VL 28
PS 110-139
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Recent phylogenetic analysis of false geckos, genus Pseudogekko,
   revealed unrecognized diversity within these exceedingly rare and
   enigmatic Philippine forest geckos. Newly available genetic datasets
   revealed that two of the four currently recognized species are complexes
   of multiple, deeply divergent evolutionary lineages. In this paper we
   evaluate species diversity in the Pseudogekko compresicorpus Complex and
   describe three new species in this unique clade of endemic Philippine
   geckos. For nearly a century, P. compresicorpus has been recognized as a
   single, "widespread'' species with a geographic range spanning three
   major faunal regions and several isolated islands. This perception of
   the species' wide geographic range has persisted due to the rarity of
   this species. We evaluate morphological data, in light of a recent
   phylogenetic study on the genus, to define species limits in P.
   compresicorpus, finding character-based evidence that unambiguously
   supports the recognition of four unique evolutionary lineages within the
   complex, three of which we describe as new species. These evolutionary
   species correspond to monophyletic lineages supported in recent
   molecular studies. We also address the historically controversial
   generic affiliation of Pseudogekko labialis and conclude that this
   poorly known species is a member of the genus Lepidodactylus. All
   species recognized in this study possess allopatric geographic ranges
   and differ from congeners by numerous diagnostic characters of external
   morphology and, therefore, should be recognized as full species in
   accordance with any lineage-based species concept. This study nearly
   doubles the known diversity of Philippine false geckos.
C1 Siler, Cameron D.; Univ Oklahoma, Dept Biol, 2401 Chautauqua Ave,
   Norman, OK, 73072, USA, USA.
EM camsiler@ou.edu
OI Davis, Drew/0000-0001-5128-4064; Watters, Jessa/0000-0002-9527-9539
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0733-1347
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; General morphology; Evolution; Evolutionary adaptation; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Pseudogekko chavacano; Pseudogekko ditoy; Pseudogekko pungkaypinit
   [Philippines /  / New species]. 
   Pseudogekko compresicorpus complex [General morphology / Morphological
   characters / systematics] [Divergence / Genetic divergence / ]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic analysis / ] [Philippines /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Lepidodactylus labialis (Gekkonidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Pseudogekko, p. 117]. 
   Pseudogekko chavacano (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 131]. 
   Pseudogekko compresicorpus complex (Gekkonidae). 
   Pseudogekko ditoy (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 128]. 
   Pseudogekko labialis (Gekkonidae): [Referred to, Lepidodactylus, p.

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103018795

AN ZOOR15103016108

DT Article
TI Sequencing of Sylvilagus VDJ genes reveals a new VHa allelic lineage and
   shows that ancient VH lineages were retained differently in leporids.
AU Pinheiro, Ana
   Melo-Ferreira, Jose
   Abrantes, Joana
   Martinelli, Nicola
   Lavazza, Antonio
   Alves, Paulo C.
   Gortazar, Christian
   Esteves, Pedro J. (pjesteves@cibio.up.pt) 
SO Immunogenetics
VL 66
IS 12
PS 719-726
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Antigen recognition by immunoglobulins depends upon initial
   rearrangements of heavy chain V, D, and J genes. In leporids, a unique
   system exists for the VH genes usage that exhibit highly divergent
   lineages: the VHa allotypes, the Lepus sL lineage and the VHn genes. For
   the European rabbit (Oryctolagus cuniculus), four VHa lineages have been
   described, the a1, a2, a3 and a4. For hares (Lepus sp.), one VHa lineage
   was described, the a2L, as well as a more ancient sL lineage. Both
   genera use the VHn genes in a low frequency of their VDJ rearrangements.
   To address the hypothesis that the VH specificities could be associated
   with different environments, we sequenced VDJ genes from a third leporid
   genus, Sylvilagus. We found a fifth and equally divergent VHa lineage,
   the a5, and an ancient lineage, the sS, related to the hares' sL, but
   failed to obtain VHn genes. These results show that the studied leporids
   employ different VH lineages in the generation of the antibody
   repertoire, suggesting that the leporid VH genes are subject to strong
   selective pressure likely imposed by specific pathogens.
C1 Esteves, Pedro J.; Univ Porto, CIBIO Ctr Invest Biodiversidade &
   Recursos Genet, Campus Agr Vairao, Vairao, P-4485661, Portugal,
   Portugal.
EM pjesteves@cibio.up.pt
RI Alves, Paulo C/B-5448-2009; Abrantes, Joana/D-3819-2012; Gortazar,
   Christian/E-7918-2012; Lavazza, Antonio/G-8182-2011; Melo-Ferreira,
   Jose/E-9784-2010; Esteves, Pedro/A-7537-2010
OI Alves, Paulo C/0000-0003-4797-0939; Abrantes, Joana/0000-0002-8391-7134;
   Gortazar, Christian/0000-0003-0012-4006; Lavazza,

DT Article
TI Egg parasitoids (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae and Trichogrammatidae) of Kolla
   paulula (Walker) (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) in Taiwan.
AU Triapitsyn, Serguei Vladimirovich
   Shih, Hsien-Tzung (serguei.triapitsyn@ucr.edu) 
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 17
IS 4
PS 673-678
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 3
U2 8
AB Pseudoligosita nephotetticum (Mani) (Hymenoptera: Trichogrammatidae) and
   Gonatocerus (Cosmocomoidea) sp. (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) have been
   identified for the first time as egg parasitoids of the sharpshooter
   leafhopper Kolla paulula (Walker) (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae:
   Cicadellinae: Cicadellini) in Taiwan. K. paulula has been recently
   identified as a candidate vector of the phytopathogenic bacterium
   Xylella fastidiosa, the causative agent of Pierce's disease of grapes
   and similar diseases of other affected plants in Taiwan, and thus has
   become of particular economic importance. Also provided is a summary of
   the known records of egg parasitoids (Mymaridae and Trichogrammatidae)
   of other leafhoppers from the tribe Cicadellini in the world, as well as
   taxonomic notes on P. nephotetticum. (C) 2014 Korean Society of Applied
   Entomology, Taiwan Entomological Society and Malaysian Plant Protection
   Society. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Shih, Hsien-Tzung; Taiwan Agr Res Inst, Appl Zool Div, 189 Chung Cheng

PM 26988787
DT Article
TI FIVE CYANOPHORA (CYANOPHORALES, GLAUCOPHYTA) SPECIES DELINEATED BASED ON
   MORPHOLOGICAL AND MOLECULAR DATA.
AU Takahashi, Toshiyuki
   Sato, Mayuko
   Toyooka, Kiminori
   Matsuzaki, Ryo
   Kawafune, Kaoru
   Kawamura, Mai
   Okuda, Kazuo
   Nozaki, Hisayoshi (nozaki@bs.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp) 
SO Journal of Phycology
VL 50
IS 6
PS 1058-1069
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 19
AB Cyanophora is an important glaucophyte genus of unicellular
   biflagellates that may have retained ancestral features of
   photosynthetic eukaryotes. The nuclear genome of Cyanophora was recently
   sequenced, but taxonomic studies of more than two strains are lacking
   for this genus. Furthermore, no study has used molecular methods to
   taxonomically delineate Cyanophora species. Here, we delimited the
   species of Cyanophora using light and electron microscopy, combined with
   molecular data from several globally distributed strains, including one
   newly established. Using a light microscope, we identified two distinct
   morphological groups: one with ovoid to ellipsoidal vegetative cells and
   another with dorsoventrally flattened or broad, bean-shaped vegetative
   cells containing duplicated plastids. Our light and scanning electron
   microscopy clearly distinguished three species with ovoid to ellipsoidal
   cells (C. paradoxa Korshikov, C. cuspidata Tos. Takah. & Nozaki sp.
   nov., and C. kugrensii Tos. Takah. & Nozaki sp. nov.) and two species
   with broad, bean-shaped cells (C. biloba Kugrens, B.L. Clay, C.J. Mey. &
   R.E. Lee and C. sudae Tos. Takah. & Nozaki sp. nov.) based on
   differences in cell shape and surface ornamentations of the vegetative
   cells under the field-emission scanning electron microscope. Molecular
   phylogenetic analyses of P700 chl a apoprotein A2 (psaB) genes and
   internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions of nuclear ribosomal DNA
   (rDNA), as well as a comparison of secondary structures of nuclear rDNA
   ITS-2 and genetic distances of psaB genes, supported the delineation of
   five morphological species of Cyanophora.
C1 Nozaki, Hisayoshi; Univ Tokyo, Grad Sch Sci, 7-3-1 Hongo, Tokyo,
   1130033, Japan, Japan.
EM nozaki@bs.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp
RI Sato, Mayuko/D-4601-2017; Toyooka, Kiminori/B-5027-2011
OI Sato, Mayuko/0000-0002-9876-5612; Matsuzaki, Ryo/0000-0002-8989-5933;
   Nozaki, Hisayoshi/0000-0002-9308-4498
SC Cell Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0022-3646
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis; Taxonomy;
   Key; Cytology; Genetics; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cyanophora [General cell ultrastructure / General morphology /
   systematics] [Molecular genetics /  / ]. 
   Cyanophora cuspidata; Cyanophora kugrensii; Cyanophora sudae [Japan /  /
   New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Cryptomonadida
OR Cyanophora - Korschikov (Cryptomonadida): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 1060; Key to species, P. 1067]. 
   Cyanophora cuspidata - Takahashi & Nozaki 2014 (Cryptomonadida): [Sp
   nov, Japan, P. 1066]. 
   Cyanophora kugrensii - Takahashi & Nozaki 2014 (Cryptomonadida): [Sp
   nov, Japan, P. 1066]. 
   Cyanophora paradoxa - Korshikov 1924 (Cryptomonadida): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 1065]. 
   Cyanophora sudae - Takahashi & Nozaki 2014 (Cryptomonadida): [Sp nov,
   Japan, P. 1066]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103016972
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15103016975
PM 26988792
DT Article
TI AILADINIUM RETICULATUM GEN. ET SP. NOV. (DINOPHYCEAE), A NEW THECATE,
   MARINE, SAND-DWELLING DINOFLAGELLATE FROM THE NORTHERN RED SEA.
AU Saburova, Maria (msaburova@gmail.com) 
   Chomerat, Nicolas
SO Journal of Phycology
VL 50
IS 6
PS 1120-1136
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB A new photosynthetic, sand-dwelling marine dinoflagellate, Ailadinium
   reticulatum gen. et sp. nov., is described from the Jordanian coast in
   the Gulf of Aqaba, northern Red Sea, based on detailed morphological and
   molecular data. A. reticulatum is a large (53-61 [mu]m long and 38-48
   [mu]m wide), dorsoventrally compressed species, with the epitheca
   smaller than the hypotheca. The theca of this new species is thick and
   peculiarly ornamented with round to polygonal depressions forming a
   foveate-reticulate thecal surface structure. The Kofoidian thecal
   tabulation is APC (Po, cp), 4', 2a, 6'', 6c, 4s, 6'''', 1p, 1'''' or
   alternatively it can be interpreted as APC, 4', 2a, 6'', 6c, 4s, 6''',
   2''''. The plate pattern of A. reticulatum is noticeably different from
   described dinoflagellate genera. Phylogenetic analyses based on the SSU
   and LSU rDNA genes did not show any supported affinities with currently
   known thecate dinoflagellates.

DT Article
TI Paleoenvironmental setting and description of an estuarine oyster reef
   in the Eocene of Patagonia, southern Argentina.
AU Rodriguez Raising, Martin
   Casadio, Silvio (scasadio@unrn.edu.ar) 
   Pearson, Nadine
   Mangano, Gabriela
   Buatois, Luis
   Griffin, Miguel
SO Journal of South American Earth Sciences
VL 56
PS 242-250
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A middle Eocene Crassostrea sp. reef near Rio Turbio, southwestern
   Patagonia (Argentina), represents the earliest record of an oyster reef
   associated with estuarine fades in the southern hemisphere, and also one
   of the few known worldwide occurring in Paleogene rocks. The reef grew
   in an outer estuary environment subject to periodic changes in salinity
   and may have reached a maturing phase. The Rio Turbio reef - by its
   dimensions, geometry, and substrate lithology- would have been located
   in a tidal channel convergence area. This reef provides new evidence
   suggesting that estuaries served as refuges for Crassostrea populations
   allowing them to disperse into fully marine environments many times
   throughout the Cenozoic. (C) 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Casadio, Silvio; Univ Nacl Rio Negro, Av Roca 1242, Gen Roca, Rio Negro,
   RA-8332, Argentina, Argentina.
EM scasadio@unrn.edu.ar

DT Article
TI Before the flood: Miocene otoliths from eastern Amazon Pirabas Formation
   reveal a Caribbean-type fish fauna.
AU Aguilera, Orange (orangel.aguilera@gmail.com) 
   Schwarzhans, Werner
   Moraes-Santos, Heloisa
   Nepomuceno, Aguinaldo
SO Journal of South American Earth Sciences
VL 56
PS 422-446
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Pirabas Formation of Early Miocene age represents the final stage of
   the central western Atlantic carbonate platform in northeastern South
   America, predating the emplacement of the Amazon delta system. The
   otolith-based fossil fish fauna is represented by 38 species typical of
   a shallow marine environment. A total of 18 species are described new to
   science from the families Congridae, Batrachoididae, Bythitidae,
   Sciaenidae and Paralichthyidae. The fish fauna was associated with high
   benthic and planktic primary productivity including seagrass meadows,
   calcareous algae and suspension-feeders. The break of todays shallow
   marine bioprovince at the Amazonas delta mouth is not evident from the
   fish fauna of the Pirabas Fm., which shows good correlation with the
   Gatunian/proto-Caribbean bioprovince known from an only slightly younger
   time window in Trinidad and Venezuela. Differences observed to those
   Early Miocene faunal associations are interpreted to be mainly due to
   stratigraphic and geographic and not environmental differences. We
   postulate that the emergence of the Amazonas river mouth close to its
   present day location has terminated the carbonate cycle of the Pirabas
   Fm. and pushed back northwards a certain proportion of the fish fauna
   here described. (C) 2014 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
C1 Aguilera, Orange; Univ Fed Fluminense, Inst Biol, Campus
   Valonguinho,Outeiro Sao Joao Batista S-N, Niteroi, RJ, BR-24020141 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.

TI New species of the scale worm genus Pholoides (Polychaeta: Sigalionidae)
   from south-east Brazil.
AU Padovanni, Nathalia (nathpadovanni@hotmail.com) 
   Zacagnini Amaral, Antonia Cecilia
SO Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom
VL 94
IS 8
PS 1587-1595
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB A new species of scale worm, Pholoides brasiliensis sp. nov., belonging
   to the family Sigalionidae, has been found in Espirito Santo, Rio de
   Janeiro and Sao Paulo States, south-east Brazil. The new species is
   mainly characterized by a long papilla in the subdistal region of the
   neuropodia and a prominent papilla on the ventral side of the
   tentaculophore. Pholoides remains species-poor compared to most
   Sigalionidae genera, and currently comprises four species.

DT Article
TI Apprehending novel biodiversity-fifteen new genera of Zealandian
   Bryozoa.
AU Gordon, Dennis P. (dennis.gordon@niwa.co.nz) 
SO Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom
VL 94
IS 8
PS 1597-1628
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Fifteen new genera of cheilostome Bryozoa are described from the New
   Zealand biogeographical region, centred on Zealandia, between 29[degree]
   and 59[degree]S latitude from shallow coastal waters to abyssal depths.
   The new genera are: Cavelliella, Mangana, Recapitulator (Calloporidae),
   Microblestrum, Stolomicropora (Pyrisinellidae), Otomicropora,
   Rosemariella (Microporidae), Bioptica, Caesiopora (Romancheinidae),
   Cheilonellopsis (Lacernidae), Xenogma (Buffonellodidae), Bountyella
   (incertae sedis), Taylorius (Escharinidae), Fovoporella
   (Schizoporellidae) and Ramicellepora (Celleporidae). Several new
   combinations are also recognized, i.e. Corbulella fossa, Fovoporella
   spectabilis, Kenaplousina canariensis, Taylorius incognitus, Taylorius
   masoni, Taylorius waiparaensis and Xenogma rhomboidale. Ten of the new
   genera are nominally endemic to the New Zealand exclusive economic zone.
   Recapitulator and Microblestrum (on seamounts near the southern part of
   the Hjort Trench) and Rosemariella (seamount in the Louisville Ridge)
   occur in extraterritorial waters, Xenogma extends to Australia and
   Taylorius extends to South Africa. Taylorius is also known from the
   Miocene and Fovoporella from the Pliocene. Recapitulator and Mangana
   have plesiomorphies that are novel among Recent Calloporidae
   (respectively a costate ooecium and 'pelmatoporine' elongate
   adventitious interzooidal kenozooids) but which are found in some
   Cretaceous calloporids or cribrilinids.

PT J
AN ZOOR15103016198
DT Article
TI Algal epibiosis on Megabalanus tintinnabulum and its role in segregation
   of the Balanus amphitrite population.
AU Eswaran, Ranjith
   Khandeparker, Lidita (klidita@nio.org) 
SO Marine Ecology
VL 35
IS 4
PS 492-505
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Ulva sp. and Gracilaria sp. were found colonizing shell surfaces of an
   acorn barnacle, Megabalanus tintinnabulum. However, this association was
   not noticed in the case of Balanus amphitrite, which was a
   co-inhabitant. Such a difference in intergeneric interactions with the
   algae was examined in laboratory experiments. For this, the influence
   that extracts of algae, extracts of algae-associated bacteria and
   natural leachants from M. tintinnabulum exerted on cyprid metamorphosis
   of B. amphitrite was examined. Extracts of algae and associated bacteria
   showed no effect on the metamorphosis of B. amphitrite. This may be
   attributed to absence of cue-specific sugars in the exopolysaccharides
   and culture supernatants of bacteria. On the other hand, natural
   leachants of M. tintinnabulum, which showed the presence of
   N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, a known algal spore attractant, also inhibited
   metamorphosis of B. amphitrite. Thus, hosting specific epibionts could
   have important roles in the segregation of barnacle population.
C1 Khandeparker, Lidita; Natl Inst Oceanog, Dona Paula, Goa, 403004, India,
   India.
EM klidita@nio.org
SC Developmental Biology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0173-9565
BD Life cycle and development; Development; Associations; Marine zones;
   Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean

   / India, Goa, Zuari Estuary, Dona Paula Bay / ]. 
   Megabalanus tintinnabulum [Associations / Gracilaria (alga) / Epibiosis]
   [ / Sargassum (alga) / ] [ / Ulva (alga) / ] [Arabian Sea / India, Goa,
   Zuari Estuary, Dona Paula Bay / Algal associates]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

PM 24810381
DT Article
TI Three new species of fleas belonging to the genus Macrostylophora from
   the three-striped ground squirrel, Lariscus insignis, in Java.
AU Durden, L.A. (ldurden@georgiasouthern.edu) 
   Beaucournu, J.-C.
SO Medical and Veterinary Entomology
VL 28
IS 4
PS 398-406
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Three new species of fleas belonging to the genus Macrostylophora
   (Siphonaptera, Ceratophyllidae) are described from the three-striped
   ground squirrel, Lariscus insignis, from Tjibodas, West Java (Jawa
   Barat), Indonesia at an elevation of 1500m. Macrostylophora larisci sp.
   n. is described from three male specimens, Macrostylophora debilitata
   sp. n. is described from one male and Macrostylophora wilsoni sp. n. is
   described from one female. Non-genital morphological characters of the
   female specimen, including ctenidial spine shapes and lengths, show that
   it is not the corresponding female for either M. larisci sp. n. or M.
   debilitata sp. n. It is unusual for three different species of
   congeneric fleas to parasitize the same host species in the same
   geographical location. These three new species represent the first known
   records of Macrostylophora from Java and they could be enzootic vectors
   between rodents of flea-borne zoonotic pathogens such as Rickettsia
   typhi and Yersinia pestis, both of which are established on Java. A list
   is provided of the 43 known species and 12 subspecies of Macrostylophora
   together with their known geographical distributions and hosts. A map
   depicting the distributions of known Indonesian (and Bornean) species of
   Macrostylophora is also included.
C1 Durden, L.A.; Georgia So Univ, Dept Biol, 4324 Old Register Rd,
   Statesboro, GA, 30460, USA, USA.
EM ldurden@georgiasouthern.edu
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0269-283X

   region; Eurasia; Asia

   species]. 
   Macrostylophora [Mammalian hosts /  / Host parasite list] [Zoogeography
   /  / ] [Indonesia /  / distribution]. 
   Macrostylophora debilitata; Macrostylophora larisci; Macrostylophora
   wilsoni [Mammalian hosts / Lariscus insignis / New parasite species]
   [Indonesia /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
   Mammalia [Siphonapteran parasites / Macrostylophora / Host parasite
   list] [Indonesia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Insects; Invertebrates; Mammals; Rodents;
   Vertebrates

PM 25238947
DT Article
TI Phylogenetic relationships of Acheilognathidae (Cypriniformes:
   Cyprinoidea) as revealed from evidence of both nuclear and mitochondrial
   gene sequence variation: Evidence for necessary taxonomic revision in
   the family and the identification of cryptic species.
AU Chang, Chia-Hao
   Li, Fan
   Shao, Kwang-Tsao
   Lin, Yeong-Shin
   Morosawa, Takahiro
   Kim, Sungmin
   Koo, Hyeyoung
   Kim, Won
   Lee, Jae-Seong
   He, Shunping
   Smith, Carl
   Reichard, Martin
   Miya, Masaki
   Sado, Tetsuya
   Uehara, Kazuhiko
   Lavoue, Sebastien
   Chen, Wei-Jen (wjchen.actinops@gmail.com) 
   Mayden, Richard L.
SO Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
VL 81
PS 182-194
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 6
U2 59
AB Bitterlings are relatively small cypriniform species and extremely
   interesting evolutionarily due to their unusual reproductive behaviors
   and their coevolutionary relationships with freshwater mussels. As a
   group, they have attracted a great deal of attention in biological
   studies. Understanding the origin and evolution of their mating system
   demands a well-corroborated hypothesis of their evolutionary
   relationships. In this study, we provide the most comprehensive
   phylogenetic reconstruction of species relationships of the group based
   on partitioned maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods using DNA
   sequence variation of nuclear and mitochondrial genes on 41 species,
   several subspecies and three undescribed species. Our findings support
   the monophyly of the Acheilognathidae. Two of the three currently
   recognized genera are not monophyletic and the family can be subdivided
   into six clades. These clades are further regarded as genera based on
   both their phylogenetic relationships and a reappraisal of morphological
   characters. We present a revised classification for the Acheilognathidae
   with five genera/lineages: Rhodeus, Acheilognathus (new constitution),
   Tanakia (new constitution), Paratanakia gen. nov., and Pseudorhodeus
   gen. nov. and an unnamed clade containing five species currently
   referred to as "Acheilognathus". Gene trees of several bitterling
   species indicate that the taxa are not monophyletic. This result
   highlights a potentially dramatic underestimation of species diversity
   in this family. Using our new phylogenetic framework, we discuss the
   evolution of the Acheilognathidae relative to classification, taxonomy
   and biogeography. (C) 2014 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
C1 Chen, Wei-Jen; Natl Taiwan Univ, Inst Oceanog, Room 301,1 Sec 4
   Roosevelt Rd, Taipei, 10617, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM wjchen.actinops@gmail.com
RI Reichard, Martin/C-6563-2009; Smith, Carl/A-2254-2015; Lee,
   Jae-Seong/H-6013-2015; CHEN, Wei-Jen/A-2605-2008; Miya,
   Masaki/O-2664-2019; Reichard, Martin/AAE-9240-2019; Lavoue,
   Sebastien/H-7118-2012
OI Lee, Jae-Seong/0000-0003-0944-5172; CHEN, Wei-Jen/0000-0003-4751-7632;
   Reichard, Martin/0000-0002-9306-0074; Lavoue,
   Sebastien/0000-0003-4798-6666; Miya, Masaki/0000-0002-9791-9886

DT Article
TI Silica-scaled chrysophytes from Hainan, Guangdong Provinces and Hong
   Kong Special Administrative Region, China.
AU Wei, Yin-Xin (wei_yinxin@qq.com) 
   Yuan, Xiu-Ping
   Kristiansen, Jorgen
SO Nordic Journal of Botany
VL 32
IS 6
PS 881-896
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 8
AB Twenty five phytoplankton samples containing chrysophytes were collected
   in Hainan and Guangdong Provinces and in Hong Kong Special
   Administrative Region in January 2010 and October to November 2011.
   Forty nine taxa of silica-scaled chrysophytes were identified by means
   of transmission electron microscopy, twelve of them belonging to
   Paraphysomonadaceae and thirty seven to Synurales. Spiniferomonas
   cornuta, Paraphysomonas sp., Mallomonas hexareticulata, M. ceylanica, M.
   plumosa, M. ocellata, M. elevata and M. spinosa are reported for the
   first time from China. A new species, Paraphysomonas hainanensis Wei &
   Kristiansen, was found in a pond in Haikou City, Hainan Province. An
   amended description of Mallomonas spinosa Gusev is proposed. The sampled
   localities are situated in the tropical and subtropical region of
   southern China. There is great similarity in the geographical
   distribution of the observed silica-scaled chrysophytes with that of
   east Asia, southeast Asia and south Asia, and their ecological
   characteristics are discussed.

DT Article
TI Chalcidoid parasitoids (Hymenoptera) of Etiella zinckenella (Treitschke)
   (Lep.: Pyralidae) on Sophora alopecuroides L. in Iran.
AU Lotfalizadeh, Hosseinali (hlotfalizadeh@gmail.com) 
   Hosseini, Farnaz
SO North-Western Journal of Zoology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 141201, 251-258
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The seeds of Sophora alopecuroidcs L. (Legominosae) are damaged by
   Eticlla zinckenella (Treitschke) (Lep.: Pyralidae) in East-Azarbaijan,
   northwestern Iran. Laboratory rearing of seeds infested E. zinckenella
   produced six chalcidoid species. These species are from the family
   Eulophidae: Aprostocetus arrabonicus (Erdos), Elasmus biroi Erdos,
   Elasmus platyedrae Ferriere; Eurytomidae: Aximopsis augasmae (Zerova)
   Comb. n., Aximopsis near ghazvini (Zerova) Comb, n.; and Pteromalidae:
   Cyrtoptyx lichtensteini (Masi). All of these species are new records for
   Iran. Associations of A. arrabonicus, E. hi rot, E. platyedrae, A.
   augasmac and A. near ghazvini with E. zinckenella are new, and
   furthermore, A. arrabonicus may be a hyperparasitoid of E. zinckenella.

TI Study of the tribe Anthidiini (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) in northern
   Iran, with the description of a new species.
AU Nadimi, Ahmad
   Talebi, Ali Asghar (talebia@modares.ac.ir) 
   Zhu, Chao-Dong
   Fathipour, Yaghoub
SO North-Western Journal of Zoology
VL 10
IS 2
PS 413-424
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Twenty six species of Anthidiini (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) belonging
   to the genera Anthidiellum (1 species), Anthidium (13 species),
   Eoanthidium (2 species), Icteranthidium (6 species), Pseudoanthidium (2
   species), Rhodanthidium (1 species) and Stelis (1 species) are recorded
   from northern Iran. Of these, a new species, Airthidium (Anthidittni)
   akanthurum sp. nov., is described and illustrated and five species are
   recorded for the first time from Iran. Information on host plants,
   distribution and an updated list of Iranian Anthidiini fauna are
   provided.

DT Article
TI Deep-sea Kinorhyncha: two new species from the Guinea Basin, with
   evaluation of an unusual male feature.
AU Sanchez, Nuria (nurisanc@bio.ucm.es) 
   Pardos, Fernando
   Sorensen, Martin V.
SO Organisms Diversity & Evolution
VL 14
IS 4
PS 349-361
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB Two new species of homalorhagid kinorhynchs from the deep-sea Guinea
   Basin are described. Pycnophyes nubilis sp. nov. is easily recognized by
   the presence of paradorsal setae on segment 1; middorsal processes on
   segments 1-10, progressively increasing in length towards the posterior
   segments; and middorsal process on segment 10 extending over the last
   trunk segment. Pycnophyes farinellii sp. nov. is distinguished by
   middorsal elevations on segments 2-9 and laterodorsal and ventromedial
   setae on segments 2 and 9 only. Moreover, males of the latter species
   lack ventromedial tubes on segment 2-a very uncommon feature among the
   genus. The systematic significance of this character is discussed in
   detail.

   Jose Antonio Novais 2, Madrid, 28040, Spain, Spain.

   PARDOS/0000-0002-6292-9793

DT Article
TI Are copepods secondary hosts of Cycliophora?
AU Neves, Ricardo Cardoso (ricardon.6@gmail.com) 
   Bailly, Xavier
   Reichert, Heinrich
SO Organisms Diversity & Evolution
VL 14
IS 4
PS 363-367
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 26
AB Ever since the first observations in the late 1960s, Cycliophora were
   found exclusively living epizoically on lobsters belonging to the family
   Nephropidae. The complex cycliophoran life cycle, with alternation of
   asexual and sexual generations, takes place only in the microhabitat
   provided by the host mouthparts. Herein, we report the first evidence of
   a symbiotic relationship between cycliophorans and organisms other than
   nephropid lobsters, namely, the harpacticoid copepods. Two specimens of
   copepods associated with cycliophoran life cycle stages were collected
   from the segmental mouthparts of a European lobster, Homarus gammarus.
   One of the copepods carried two feeding stages with long stalks, which
   probably belong to an undescribed Symbion sp., while the other copepod
   was found bearing an undetermined settled stage. We discuss the
   implications of these novel observations for the understanding of the
   Cycliophora life cycle and their dispersion abilities.
C1 Neves, Ricardo Cardoso; Univ Basel, Biozentrum, Klingelbergstr 50,
   Basel, CH-4056, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM ricardon.6@gmail.com
RI Neves, Ricardo Cardoso/J-9822-2014
OI Neves, Ricardo Cardoso/0000-0002-9219-9066

   Developmental Biology
SN 1439-6092

DT Article
TI Two New Species of Chigger Mites in the Genus Gahrliepia (Acari:
   Trombiculidae) from China.
AU Ren, Tian-Guang
   Guo, Xian-Guo (xianguoguo@yahoo.com) 
   Jin, Dao-Chao
SO Pakistan Journal of Zoology
VL 46
IS 6
PS 1657-1662
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB This paper describes two new species of chigger mites, Gahrliepia
   eothenomydis, n. sp. and Gahrliepia gengmaensis, n. sp., that live on
   two species of rodents found in the Yunnan province of southwest China.
   Specifically, the specimens were collected from Eothenomys miletus
   (Thomas 1914) and Rattus sladeni (Linnaeus 1758). The leg segmentations
   of the two new species are 7.6.6. The length of their scutum is longer
   than its breadth and neither species has an anteromedian projection nor
   an anteromedian seta (AM). On the scutum, there are no inter medial
   setae between the sensilla. The formula of the palpotarsus (if) for the
   two new species are both 4B (B=branched), and fp (formula of palpal
   seta) = B/N/N/N/B (N=naked). The former new species (Gahrliepia
   eothenomydis, n. sp.) has two sensillae clavates with barbs on their
   shafts. There are 19 scutal setae on the scutum. The fDS (formula of
   dorsal setation) = 2.2.4.10.10.8.2.4 = 42, VS (number of ventral setae)
   = 60, and PPLs (posterior posterolateral setaes) = 15. In the later new
   species (Gahrliepia gengmaensis, n. sp.), two sensilla elevates were
   lost. There are 23 scutal setae on its scutum. The fDS =
   2.2.2.4.2.6.8.4, VS = 44, and PPLs = 19. These two new species increase
   the number of Gahrliepia species in China to 39 species.
C1 Guo, Xian-Guo; Guizhou Univ, Inst Entomol, Guiyang, 550025, China,
   China.
EM xianguoguo@yahoo.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China

   parasite species] [Yunnan /  / New arachnid parasite species]. 
   Gahrliepia eothenomydis [Mammalian hosts / Eothenomys miletus / New
   parasite species] [Yunnan /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
   Gahrliepia gengmaensis [Mammalian hosts / Rattus sladeni / New parasite
   species] [Yunnan /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
   Rattus sladeni [Arachnid parasites / Gahrliepia gengmaensis / New
   parasite species] [Yunnan /  / New arachnid parasite species].

DT Article
TI Middle Ottnangian (late Burdigalian) mollusks from the Rott Valley (SE
   Germany): the ultimate marine fauna of the Western Paratethys.
AU Schneider, Simon (simon.schneider@casp.cam.ac.uk) 
   Mandic, Oleg
SO Palaeontologische Zeitschrift
VL 88
IS 4
PS 375-403
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB The Bivalvia and Gastropoda from the Upper Marine Molasse deposits of
   the lower Rott Valley (North Alpine Foreland Basin, Lower Bavaria, SE
   Germany) comprise the first mollusk fauna of middle Ottnangian age (ca
   17.5 Ma) to be documented in detail. Altogether, the assemblages from
   Brombach, Kainerding and Anzenkirchen yielded 27 species of Bivalvia and
   9 species of Gastropoda. The bivalve species Spisula brombachensis n.
   sp. is described as new to science, and Aequipecten camaretensis is
   first reported from the Ottnangian of the North Alpine Foreland Basin.
   Furthermore, the well-preserved material allowed for the taxonomic
   revision of the Ottnangian index fossil Pecten herrmannseni. The bivalve
   community is dominated by suspension feeders, mostly shallow, soft
   bottom dwellers (Glycymeris, Anadara) and cementing epifauna (Ostrea).
   Gastropods almost exclusively comprise carnivorous browsers and
   predators. The parautochthonous assemblages are indicative of normal
   marine, well-oxygenized sandy-silty shoals at a water depth of
   presumably less than 20 m. Except for the presence of a single estuarine
   Crassostrea, the middle Ottnangian fauna is not indicative of reduced
   salinities. Consequently, the paleoenvironmental turnover to the
   brackish-water fauna of the directly overlying upper Ottnangian deposits
   of the Rzehakia Lake was abrupt. Glycymeris-Anadara-Ostrea communities
   similar to the one recorded from the Rott Valley are widespread in
   European seas and beyond during the Neogene and Quaternary.
C1 Schneider, Simon; CASP, West Bldg,181A Huntingdon Rd, Cambridge, CB3
   0DH, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM simon.schneider@casp.cam.ac.uk
OI Schneider, Simon/0000-0001-6493-357X
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0031-0220

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene

PT J
AN ZOOR15103016274
DT Article
TI Diversity, palaeoecology and systematics of a marine fossil assemblage
   from the Late Triassic Cassian Formation at Settsass Scharte, N Italy.
AU Nuetzel, Alexander (a.nuetzel@lrz.uni-muenchen.de) 
   Kaim, Andrzej
SO Palaeontologische Zeitschrift
VL 88
IS 4
PS 405-431
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A marine fossil assemblage from the Late Triassic (Early Carnian)
   Cassian Formation is reported. It was retrieved by bulk sampling,
   including wet sieving and quantitative picking, and by quantitative
   surface collection. The collection consists of c. 460 specimens
   (foraminiferans not included) representing 54 species. In terms of
   abundance and species richness, it is strongly dominated by molluscs,
   especially gastropods. 97 % of the individuals are molluscs. The most
   abundant species are the gastropods Goniospira armata, Schartia carinata
   and Helenostylina convexa, followed by the scaphopod Plagioglypta
   undulata and the bivalve Palaeonucula strigilata. Disarticulated
   echinoderm ossicles (mostly echinoids, crinoids, few holothurians)
   comprise almost all of the rest of the assemblage. The studied
   assemblage shows moderate diversity, similar to those of previously
   reported assemblages or associations from basinal settings. However, it
   differs considerably in taxonomic composition from previously described
   associations of the Cassian Formation. The abundance of small gastropods
   is a result of their primary abundance in these ancient living
   communities and of the sampling method (sieving at 0.5 mm), because most
   of the previous associations were obtained by performing surface
   collections, in which small gastropods are easily overlooked. The fauna
   is interpreted as an autochthonous soft bottom assemblage dominated by
   species that lived in low epifaunal to shallow infaunal habitats.
   Detritivory, deposit feeding and microcarnivory represent the main
   feeding types. Most of the species were fully motile but slow, and
   either infaunal (scaphopods, nuculids, the gastropod Domerionina) or
   epifaunal (most other gastropods, echinoids). The present assemblage
   underlines the pronounced heterogeneity of the Cassian biota. The low
   grade of lithification and diagenetic alteration facilitates bulk
   sampling and the investigation of small species. This minimizes possible
   sampling and preservation biases, so the studied assemblage reflects the
   alpha diversity of this ancient living community to an unusually high
   degree. The following gastropod taxa are new: Helenostylina convexa n.
   sp., Schartia carinata n. gen. n. sp., Schartiinae n. subfam.;
   Cassianastraea Bandel non Volz is replaced with Bandelastraea nom. nov.
C1 Nuetzel, Alexander; Univ Munich, Geobioctr, Munich, D-80333, Germany,
   Germany.
EM a.nuetzel@lrz.uni-muenchen.de
RI Kaim, Andrzej/G-6244-2010; Nutzel, Alexander/G-2798-2015
OI Kaim, Andrzej/0000-0001-6186-5356; Nutzel, Alexander/0000-0002-8852-7688
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0031-0220
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Available name; Ecology;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic

   Schartiinae [Triassic /  / New subfamily].

   Archaeogastropoda
OR Gastropoda (Mollusca): [Fossil]. 
   Schartia (Heterobranchia): [Gen nov, Of new subfamily Schartiinae, Type
   species Schartia carinata, p. 419, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Schartia carinata (Heterobranchia): [Sp nov, Italy, Triassic, P. 419;
   Fossil]. 
   Schartiinae (Heterobranchia): [Subfam nov, Of family Tofanellidae, Type
   genus Schartia, p. 419, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Goniospira - Cossmann 1896 (Prosobranchia): [Emended diagnosis, P. 415].

   diagnosis, P. 415]. 
   Helenostylina convexa (Prosobranchia): [Sp nov, Italy, Triassic, P. 418;
   Fossil]. 
   Bandelastraea (Archaeogastropoda): [Nom nov, For Cassianastraea Bandel,
   p. 405]. 
   Cassianastraea - Bandel (Archaeogastropoda): [Preoccupied name replaced
   by, Bandelastraea, p. 405].

PT J
AN ZOOR15103016275
DT Article
TI New bethylid and chrysidid wasps (Hymenoptera: Chrysidoidea) from
   Canadian Late Cretaceous amber.
AU McKellar, Ryan C. (ryan.mckellar@ku.edu) 
   Engel, Michael S.
SO Palaeontologische Zeitschrift
VL 88
IS 4
PS 433-451
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new bethylid species, Celonophamia granama, and two new chrysidid
   species, Procleptes eoliami, and P. hopejohnsonae, are described from
   Late Cretaceous (Campanian) amber collected at the Grassy Lake locality
   in Alberta, Canada. Within the deposit these taxa constitute the first
   bethylid, and the second and third chrysidid species to be described,
   respectively. The new taxa expand the sparse fossil record of
   Chrysidoidea, particularly that of Chrysididae-a group that was
   previously represented by only three described species in the Mesozoic.
   The presence of Celonophamia species in both Canadian amber and Siberian
   (Taimyr) amber further emphasizes faunal similarities between these two
   northern Late Cretaceous amber deposits. Given the prevalence of
   metallic coloration in Chrysididae, the specimens described here also
   provide evidence for the taphonomic alteration of perceived insect
   colors in Cretaceous amber inclusions.
C1 McKellar, Ryan C.; Univ Alberta, Dept Earth & Atmospher Sci, 1-26 Earth
   Sci Bldg, Edmonton, AB, T6G 2E3, Canada, Canada.
EM ryan.mckellar@ku.edu
RI Engel, Michael S/C-5461-2012
OI Engel, Michael S/0000-0003-3067-077X

SN 0031-0220

   Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Alberta /  / new species; Described from amber] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Canada /  / ] [Cretaceous / Campanian / ].

DT Article
TI A new trap-jaw ant species of the genus Odontomachus (Hymenoptera:
   Formicidae: Ponerinae) from the Early Miocene (Burdigalian) of the Czech
   Republic.
AU Wappler, Torsten (twappler@uni-bonn.de) 
   Dlussky, Gennady M.
   Engel, Michael S.
   Prokop, Jakub
   Knor, Stanislav
SO Palaeontologische Zeitschrift
VL 88
IS 4
PS 495-502
PD Dec 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Odontomachus paleomyagra sp. nov. is described from the Early Miocene of
   the Most Basin (Czech Republic) on the basis of a single-winged female,
   representing one of the rare reports of fossil Odontomachini. The new
   species is separated easily from other trap-jaw ant species groups by
   differences in mandibular morphology (without denticles on the inner
   side) and distributional occurrence. The evolutionary and biogeographic
   history of the Odontomachini is briefly discussed.
C1 Wappler, Torsten; Univ Bonn, Steinmann Inst, Nussallee 8, Bonn, D-53115,
   Germany, Germany.
EM twappler@uni-bonn.de

   Torsten/P-6831-2019; Wappler, Torsten/D-4287-2011
OI Engel, Michael S/0000-0003-3067-077X; Prokop, Jakub/0000-0001-6996-7832;
   Wappler, Torsten/0000-0003-1592-0988; Wappler,
   Torsten/0000-0003-1592-0988
